DataElement.preferredName: Anaplastic Thyroid Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Stage group determined from information on the tumor (T), regional node (N) and metastases (M) and by grouping cases with similar prognosis for anaplastic cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma Stage Grouping
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A primary carcinoma of the thyroid gland composed of undifferentiated cells.  The malignant cells demonstrate evidence of epithelial differentiation, either by immunohistochemistry or electron microscopic studies. Microscopically, in the majority of cases there is a mixture of spindle, epithelioid, and giant cells. The vast majority of the patients present with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The clinical course is usually aggressive._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A primary carcinoma of the thyroid gland composed of undifferentiated cells.  The malignant cells demonstrate evidence of epithelial differentiation, either by immunohistochemistry or electron microscopic studies. Microscopically, in the majority of cases there is a mixture of spindle, epithelioid, and giant cells. The vast majority of the patients present with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The clinical course is usually aggressive.

Concepts.definition: A primary carcinoma of the thyroid gland composed of undifferentiated cells.  The malignant cells demonstrate evidence of epithelial differentiation, either by immunohistochemistry or electron microscopic studies. Microscopically, in the majority of cases there is a mixture of spindle, epithelioid, and giant cells. The vast majority of the patients present with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The clinical course is usually aggressive.

Property.preferredDefinition: Stage Grouping; an assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage. (caDSR)

Concepts.definition: An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8-30-19 TMT transferred from NCIP to NCI Standards. Created for CRF standard harmonization. mc 5/17/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A primary carcinoma of the thyroid gland composed of undifferentiated cells.  The malignant cells demonstrate evidence of epithelial differentiation, either by immunohistochemistry or electron microscopic studies. Microscopically, in the majority of cases there is a mixture of spindle, epithelioid, and giant cells. The vast majority of the patients present with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The clinical course is usually aggressive._A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding indicating that the extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

Concepts.definition: The extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage IVA Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage IVA Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVA includes: T4a, Any N, M0.  T4a: Intrathyroidal anaplastic carcinoma. M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVA Thyroid Gland Anaplastic Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVA includes: T4a, Any N, M0.  T4a: Intrathyroidal anaplastic carcinoma. M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage IVB Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage IVB Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVB includes: T4b, Any N, M0.  T4b: Anaplastic carcinoma with gross extrathyroid extension.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVB Thyroid Gland Anaplastic Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVB includes: T4b, Any N, M0.  T4b: Anaplastic carcinoma with gross extrathyroid extension.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage IVC Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage IVC Thyroid Gland Undifferentiated (Anaplastic) Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVC includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVC Thyroid Gland Anaplastic Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVC includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A primary carcinoma of the thyroid gland composed of undifferentiated cells.  The malignant cells demonstrate evidence of epithelial differentiation, either by immunohistochemistry or electron microscopic studies. Microscopically, in the majority of cases there is a mixture of spindle, epithelioid, and giant cells. The vast majority of the patients present with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The clinical course is usually aggressive.:A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A primary carcinoma of the thyroid gland composed of undifferentiated cells.  The malignant cells demonstrate evidence of epithelial differentiation, either by immunohistochemistry or electron microscopic studies. Microscopically, in the majority of cases there is a mixture of spindle, epithelioid, and giant cells. The vast majority of the patients present with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The clinical course is usually aggressive.
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ReferenceDocuments.name: AJCC 7th Edition Manual Note
ReferenceDocuments.description: All anaplastic carcinomas are considered Stage IV
